column1: The Insurgency in the Maghreb refers to the Islamist insurgency in the Maghreb and Sahel regions of North Africa that followed on from the Algerian Civil War. The Algerian militant group Salafist Group for Preaching and Combat (GSPC) allied itself with al-Qaeda to eventually become al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM). The Algerian and other Maghreb governments fighting the militants have worked with the United States and the United Kingdom since 2007
column2: when Operation Enduring Freedom – Trans Sahara began. While the 2011 Arab Spring affected support for the insurgency
column3: it also presented military opportunities for the jihadists. In 2012
column4: AQIM and Islamist allies captured the northern half of Mali
column5: until being fought back less than a year later following a French-led foreign intervention
column6: which was succeeded by the Sahel-wide Operation Barkhane. In Libya
column7: the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL) has been able to control some limited territory in the ongoing civil war since 2014
column8: amid allegations of local collaboration between the rival AQIM and ISIL.

column1: With the decline of the Armed Islamic Group of Algeria (GIA)
column2: the GSPC was left as the most active rebel group
column3: with about 300 fighters in 2003. It continued an assassination campaign of police and army personnel in its area
column4: and also managed to expand into the Sahara
column5: where its southern division
column6: led by Amari Saifi (nicknamed "Abderrezak el-Para"
column8: kidnapped a number of German tourists in 2003
column9: before being forced to flee to sparsely populated areas of Mali

column1: Some believe that el-Para actually works for the Algerian government. By late 2003
column2: the group's founder had been supplanted by the even more radical Nabil Sahraoui
column3: who announced his open support for al-Qaeda
column4: thus strengthening government ties between the U.S. and Algeria. He was reportedly killed shortly afterwards
column5: and was succeeded by Abu Musab Abdel Wadoud in 2004.The GSPC has declared its intention to attack Algerian
column6: French
column7: and American targets. It has been designated as a Foreign Terrorist Organization by the U.S. Department of State
column8: and similarly classed as a terrorist organization by the European Union.

column1: The conflict with the GSPC continued to result in a significant number of casualties in Algeria
column2: with over 1
column3: 100 killed in clashes with Islamist rebels in 2002. In 2003
column4: a total 1
column5: 162 were killed in clashes in Algeria
column6: followed by 429 killed in 2004
column9: the head of the Algerian national police claimed that terrorism had nearly been eliminated in the country
column11: and 2007 would eventually mark a height of suicide bombings and terrorist attacks in Algeria.

column1: In order to improve recruiting and funding
column2: the GSPC aligned itself with al-Qaeda
column3: and on 11 September 2006
column4: al-Qaeda leader Ayman al-Zawahiri announced a union between the groups. The GSPC rebranded itself as al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM) in January 2007
column5: signaling the broadened aspirations of the group.The group now aimed to overthrow all North African governments deemed apostate
column6: including those of Algeria
column10: Morocco and Tunisia. Operations were shifted into two broader "sectors"
column11: Northern Algeria and Tunisia allocated a "central emirate"
column14: Mauritania and Libya a "Sahara emirate" led by Djamel Okacha. The strategic leadership of AQIM continued to be headquartered in the mountainous region of Kabylie east of the Algerian capital Algiers
column15: headed by a 14-member Shura council leadership.As the Algerian counterterrorism campaign became largely successful in pushing AQIM out of the country
column16: the group established new bases in Sahel countries such as Niger
column18: Chad and Mali. Attacks against government and military installations were frequently underreported by Western media. In 2007
column19: the United States and United Kingdom launched the Operation Enduring Freedom – Trans Sahara in support of governments in the region.Frequent kidnappings of foreigners in 2008 led the Dakar Rally to be cancelled and permanently moved to South America.

column1: In the earliest major attack as direct spillover of the Algerian conflict
column2: the Mauritanian army base Lemgheity was attacked by the GSPC in June 2005
column3: killing 17 soldiers (and nine jihadists)
column4: and wounding another 17. The attack in part led to a coup d'état in October 2005 by Mohamed Ould Abdel Aziz
column5: who made a campaign against jihadists a major part of his rule. Attacks continued in Mauritania until it was largely successful in thwarting attacks since 2011 following a major military boost and political openings for Islamists. AQIM has however continued to remain active in the eastern border-regions with Mali
column6: with active support systems for logistics and information. A lack of military resources
column7: often due to turmoil and having little population in a very large country
column8: caused Mauritania to rely on support from France
column10: and Algeria in order to defeat the AQIM.

column1: In December 2006 and again in January 2007
column2: Tunisian security forces engaged in clashes with a group linked to the GSPC that had established training camps in mountainous areas near the capital Tunis
column3: killing more than a dozen people. According to French daily Le Parisien at least 60 people were killed in the clashes. The clashes were the most serious terrorist activity in Tunisia since the Ghriba synagogue bombing in 2002.Starting in 2012
column4: AQIM along with Ansar al-Sharia and the Uqba ibn Nafi Brigade active in the mountainous Jebel ech Chambi region outside Kasserine near the Algerian border have been targeted by the Tunisian Army in the Chaambi Operations. In 2014
column5: Uqba ibn Nafi Brigade militants attacked two Tunisian military checkpoints
column6: killing fourteen Tunisian soldiers and injuring twenty-five in what was the deadliest military skirmish in Tunisia since its independence in 1956. Since 2015
column7: Tunisia has simultaneously been targeted by an ISIL terrorist campaign. In March 2016 over 50 militants were killed when ISIL attempted to seize Ben Guerdane near the Libyan border.

column1: Since the Libyan Civil War in 2011
column2: south-western Libya has offered sanctuaries to AQIM which has dispatched cells to be established in the region. On 11 September 2012
column3: members of Ansar al-Sharia and AQIM were responsible for coordinated attacks against two United States government facilities in Benghazi
column4: and Ansar al-Sharia was later involved in clashes in Benghazi in 2013. Drawing defectors from AQIM
column5: the rival Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL) was later able to control some limited territory in the north in the renewed civil war from 2014. After initial official support from AQIM
column6: allegations have continued of local collaboration between the otherwise rivalling groups. After being pushed out of Derna
column7: the remaining ISIL stronghold of Sirte was captured in late 2016. Al-Qaeda-affiliated Islamists led by Ansar al-Sharia have at the same time continued to exert control in other places.

column2: AQIM and allied Islamist groups Ansar Dine and Movement for Oneness and Jihad in West Africa (MOJWA) were able to capture the northern half of Mali after effectively overrunning the preceding Tuareg rebellion
column3: which in turn had been sparked by former Tuareg fighters from the Libyan Civil War. In 2012 Malian President Amadou Toumani Touré was ousted in a coup d'état over his handling of the conflict. After Ansar Dine attempted a push into the south of the country
column4: Mali requested France to launch a military intervention in January 2013 which successfully pushed rebels out. The military intervention was followed by an ongoing Sahel-wide French-led military operation with around 4
column5: 000 French soldiers actively deployed.Small pockets of armed Islamists have remained active in northern Mali
column6: and attacks have continued against the UN peacekeeping mission MINUSMA
column7: which has become one of the UN's deadliest international missions.

column1: Having cooperated and trained alongside AQIM in the Sahel since 2006
column2: the Nigerian Islamist group Boko Haram began expanding into Chad and Niger in 2014 after successfully seizing territory in the insurgency in Nigeria. By then controlling a significant area around Lake Chad
column3: a coalition of Western African countries launched an offensive against the group in January 2015. The group eventually departed its alliance with al-Qaeda
column4: pledging allegiance to ISIL in March 2015. By the end of 2015 Boko Haram had been largely pushed to retreat into the Sambisa Forest in Nigeria
column5: although attacks have continued including in Niger.

column1: Algerian Civil War with the GIA is considered to have ended in February 2002
column2: GSPC continues insurgency.
2002 - Ghriba synagogue bombing killed 22 (14 German tourists
column3: 5 Tunisians
column4: and 2 French nationals and the suicide bomber).

column2: 2002 - 15 government soldiers are killed in an ambush near Tizi Ouzou
column3: in the Kabylie region of northern Algeria. About 50 members of the Salafist Group for Preaching and Combat (GSPC) were blamed for the assault.

column2: 2002 - Militants killed 6 civilians in an attack on youths playing football near a bus station in Zéralda in suburban Algiers.
2002 - Militants killed 7 civilians in Ouled Allal

column2: 2002 - Militants killed 11 civilians on a road in Ain Defla Province

column1: Between February 22 and March 24 of 2003 - The Free Salafist Group (GSL)

17 hostages are released and 2 militants are killed in a gun battle in the Algerian desert. The remaining fighters

column2: 2003 - In Messad

column1: Al Qaeda's wing in north Africa claimed to have killed 120 Algerian soldiers and wounded 530 in clashes in its eastern stronghold
column2: where the army has launched a campaign against the rebels. In an Internet statement posted on March 8
column4: the group denied a newspaper report that 25 of its fighters had been killed and played down reports its leader had been surrounded.

column2: 2008 - A roadside bomb killed six soldiers and wounded four in Cap Djenat. The bombing came a day after a suicide bomber targeted a military barracks in an eastern Algiers suburb but killed only himself.
2008 - 2 bombs in quick succession rocked a train station in Beni Amrane
column3: about 60 miles east of Algiers. The first bomb killed a Frenchman working on a renovation project at the station along with his driver. The second bomb came about five minutes later hitting the first responders and killing 8 soldiers and 3 firefighters.

column2: 2008 - A Moroccan court convicted a cell of 29 recruiters and sentenced them to prison.
2008 - Moroccan forces arrested 35 Al Qaeda recruiters.
2008 - A leader of Al-Qaida in Algeria was killed in a security forces raid.
2008 - A suicide car-bomber attacked a police academy in Les Issers as recruits lined up in front of the building
column3: 43 people were killed
column4: only one of them a policeman. This attack was officially condemned by the United Nations Security Council.

column2: 2008 - 2 car bombs exploded at a hotel in Bouira killing 11 civilians a day after the car bomb attack in Les Issers.
2008 - 12 Mauritanians were captured and later beheaded in northern Mauritania.
2009 - The bubonic plague infected and killed at least 40 members of AQIM in a training camp.
2009 - Gunmen abducted a Swiss couple
column3: a German woman
column4: and a British man in Niger. In February
column5: Al-Qaeda in the Maghreb claimed to have abducted the four tourists as well as Canadian diplomat Robert Fowler in December. Fowler and three others were released in April while the British man
column6: Edwin Dyer

column2: 2009 - Militants attack a gas installation at the Ziama Mansouriah commune in the coastal province of Jijel
column3: killing 9 security guards in the deadliest strike since August.

column2: 2009 - 18 gendarmerie troops and a civilian were killed in an attack on a military convoy near Bordj Bou Arréridj
column3: about 125 miles southeast of Algiers. Local sources said that the soldiers were returning after escorting to base a group of Chinese workers building the future motorway intended to cross the whole of the north African country from east to west.

column2: 2009 - At least 14 Algerian security guards were killed in an ambush by alleged Islamic fighters.
2009 - 2009 Nouakchott suicide bombing.
2009 - 2 brothers suspected of links to AQIM were arrested in France. One of the two was a CERN researcher.
2009 - Frenchman Pierre Camatte was kidnapped in Ménaka

column3: Albert Vilalta

column5: while Pascual and Vilalta was released in August 2010.

column2: 2009 - An Italian and his wife from Burkina Faso were kidnapped in eastern Mauritania. They were released on April 19

column2: 2010 - A bomb exploded at the passage of a freight train loan Timezrit. Nobody was injured.

column2: 2010 - 3 militants were killed by security forces near El Ma Labiod

column2: 2010 - 2 soldiers were killed and five others wounded in an attack in the city of Kadiria.
2010 - 3 militants were killed while another was captured by security forces in Ait Yahia Moussa
column3: 30 km from Tizi Ouzou.

column2: 2010 - A bomb attack against a taxi killed 2 people in Tizi-Ouzou. Another attack against a police patrol resulted in no injuries.
2010 - 7 security officers and a soldier were killed in a double bomb attack in the region of Béjaïa. 2 other soldiers were wounded in the second explosion.
2010 - According to Algerian officials
column3: at least 10 militants were killed since a counter-terrorist operation started in Bordj Bou Arreridj raion. The operation is ongoing. Top militant Abdelmalek Droukdel could be surrounded with other militants
column4: a military spokesman said.

column2: 2010 - At least 9 policemen were killed and another was slightly wounded when a bomb exploded in Irraguern (between Béjaïa and Jijel) while they were passing by. No other details have been reported.
2010 - A fierce gunbattle between Algerian army and a group of militants occurred near Tidjellabine (2 km from Boumerdes). It is known that one soldier was killed
column3: but the counter-terrorist operation was still going on according to Algerian officials.

column2: 2010 - One militant was killed in a clash with Algerian forces in a forest between Akfadou and Adekar. "He was wearing an old military jacket (...) he was killed on the spot" a military spokesman said. "The counter-terrorist operation is still going on" he added. This heavily forested area is often the scene of clashes between militants from Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM
column3: former GSPC) and Algerian army.

column2: 2010 - 3 militants
column3: including the emir of "Takhoukht Jamaat" Zakaria Abdelkahar
column4: were killed by security forces in Draa El Mizen (45 km from Tizi-Ouzou). It was reported that the authorities demanded them to stop their car and to surrender
column5: but they refused and were killed. Several weapons and a large amount of ammunition were discovered in the car. No other details have been reported.

column2: 2010 - 2 people including a child were killed in an ambush in Kabylie. Another person is missing.

column3: including 3 policemen
column4: four civilians and a Chinese national. Thus a score of wounded including 10 policemen and 10 civilians. At least three terrorists were killed during the violent clash that occurred after the blast.

column2: 2010 - 5 people were killed and one wounded by gunfire during a wedding at douar Ghrab near Tébessa.

2010 - 4 soldiers were killed and 13 others wounded in several bomb attacks.

column3: Mohammed Idir

column2: 2011 - One militant was wounded and policemen recovered two Kalashnikovs in a clash near Tizi-Ouzou.

column1: February 14 - At least 31 people were killed when armed men stormed the central Mali village of Ogossagou. Several members of a quick reaction force sent by MINUSMA to the village during the attack were wounded. On the same day
column2: eight soldiers were killed and four more injured in an ambush in central Gao region
column3: while a soldier was killed in an attack on a military camp in Mondoro.

column1: February 16 - Gunmen killed 24 people and wounded 18 more in an attack on a church in Yagha province
column2: northern Burkina Faso. Last week
column3: a pastor was killed and another abducted in the same province.

column1: February 17 - A French soldier died in unspecified circumstances in Burkina Faso.
February 27 - The African Union announced the deployment of an anti-terrorism force of 3
column2: 000 soldiers in the Sahel to combat the rising insecurity there.

column1: March 6 - Two militants on a motorbike blew themselves up outside the US embassy in Tunisia
column2: killing a policeman and injuring five more.

column1: March 9 - At least 43 people were killed during an attack on two Fulani villages in Yatenga Province
column2: northern Burkina Faso. The perpetrators were likely militiamen that blame the Fulani people for harboring extremist groups in the country.

column1: March 13 - An Italian man and a Canadian woman were released in Kidal
column2: Mali
column3: after being kidnapped by a militant group Burkina Faso in December 2018.

column1: March 19 - Militants attacked an army base in Tarkint
column2: Gao Province
column3: northern Mali
column4: killing at least 29 soldiers and leaving five more wounded.

column1: March 25 - The Malian URD opposition leader Soumaila Cisse was abducted along with six others near Niafunké
column2: central Mali. The abductors killed his bodyguard and wounded two more.

column1: March 29 - Nine people were killed when their vehicle hit a landmine in central Mali.
March 30 - Three soldiers were killed and another three were wounded when their vehicle struck a roadside bomb in central Mali.
April 6 - At least 25 soldiers were killed in an attack on a military base in Bamba
column2: northern Mali.

column1: April 9 - President Idriss Déby of Chad said his country's troops will no longer engage in military operations abroad in order to focus on fighting militants and rebels at home. Chad is part of MNJTF
column2: which focuses on fighting extremists in the Lake Chad region
column3: and the G5 Sahel force
column4: which focuses on fighting extremists in the Sahel region. Thousands of Chadian soldiers will withdraw from bases in Niger
column5: Mali
column6: and Nigeria by April 22.

column1: April 10 - Security forces allegedly executed 31 unarmed Fulani people hours after arresting them in Djibo
column2: northern Burkina Faso.

column1: May 1 - A French Foreign Legion soldier died of his injuries after being wounded last week by an IED explosion on his tank in Mali.
May 10 - At least 20 people were killed by gunmen in the Tillaberi region of southwest Niger. Meanwhile
column2: three Chadian soldiers were killed and four more seriously wounded when their convoy hit a roadside bomb in Aguelhok
column3: northern Mali.

column1: May 11 - A clash between the Burkinabe military and armed militants in Yagha Province left eight soldiers and 20 militants dead.
May 27 - Ethnic clashes between Fulani herdsmen and Dogon tribesmen in central Mali left 27 civilians dead.
May 28 - An attack on a rebel camp in a province in northern Burkina Faso left 10 militants and one soldier dead
column2: according to reports.

column1: May 29 - An attack on a trading convoy in Loroum Province
column2: northern Burkina Faso
column3: left at least 15 people dead and several more wounded.

column1: May 30 - An aid convoy was attacked by militants near Barsalogho
column2: northern Burkina Faso
column3: leaving at least five civilians and five gendarmes dead.

column1: May 31 - Militants attacked a market in Kompienbiga
column2: Burkina Faso
column3: killing around 30 people before fleeing on motorbikes. Meanwhile
column4: in the Tahoua Region of western Niger
column5: about 50 gunmen stormed the Intikane refugee camp
column6: killing at least three camp officials and destroying parts of the camp before fleeing.

column1: June 3 - The French army and local partners killed Abdelmalek Droukdel
column2: the leader of AQIM
column3: along with some of his associates during an operation in northern Mali. The French also stated that they were holding an ISGA leader who was captured in Mali on May 19. Meanwhile
column4: an attack on the Fulani village of Niangassadiou in Mopti region
column5: Mali
column6: left 14 villagers dead.

column1: June 5 - An attack on the Fulani village of Binedama in Mopti region
column2: Mali
column3: left 29 villagers dead and the village burned down.

column1: June 11 - Militants in Burkina Faso attacked an Ivory Coast border post
column2: killing 10 soldiers and wounding six more
column3: while one militant was killed. The attack was the first on the country since the 2016 Grand-Bassam shootings.

column1: June 12 - Two UN peacekeepers were killed during an attack on their convoy between Tessalit and Gao in Mali's north.
June 14 - An ambush of a convoy near Bouka Were
column2: central Mali
column3: left "dozens" of soldiers killed or missing. At least 24 were confirmed dead while another 12 remain missing.

column1: June 21 - A security operation in Algeria's central region of Aïn Defla left one Algerian soldier dead following an ambush.
June 24 - Armed men abducted 10 aid workers distributing food in a village in the Tillaberi region of southwest Niger.
June 27 - A bomb exploded during a sweep operation by the Algerian military in Médéa Province
column2: south of Algiers
column3: killing two soldiers
column4: including an officer.

column1: July 1 - At least 32 civilians were killed when they were shot at by gunmen on motorbikes in an attack on four ethnic Dogon villages in central Mali's Mopti region.
July 2 - Soldiers investigating the massacre yesterday in Mali's Mopti region were themselves attacked
column2: leaving nine soldiers dead and two more wounded.
a town mayor
column3: and two "trackers" were killed when militants ambushed a convoy escorting Pensa town hall members
column4: northern Burkina Faso. Three others also went missing.

column1: July 8 - A Human Rights Watch report claimed that at least 180 recently deceased corpses were found in mass graves in Djibo
column2: northern Burkina Faso
column3: with the watch group alleging they were killed by government forces.

column1: July 16 - At least 12 Dogon villagers were killed in central Mali when they were attacked by gunmen on motorcycles.
July 20 - Two soldiers were killed and five more were wounded in an attack by militants on a Burkina Faso town in Komondjari Province.
July 23 - A French soldier was killed during a firefight in Mali after he stepped on an explosive.
August 2 - Twin attacks in Ségou Region
column2: central Mali
column3: left five soldiers dead.

column1: August 7 - About 20 people were killed by militants during an attack on a cattle market in Fada N'Gourma
column2: eastern Burkina Faso.

column1: August 9 - Six French aidworkers and two Nigerien volunteers were killed when they were attacked by militants near Kouré
column2: in southwest Niger.

column1: September 4 - An ambush on a troop convoy left 10 Malian soldiers dead in Nara
column2: Mali.

column1: September 5 - Two French soldiers were killed and a third was injured when their vehicle was hit by an IED in Tessalit Province
column2: Mali.

column1: September 26 - Six militia fighters were killed when jihadists attack them.
October 8 - 25 men were killed in Burkina Faso when unknown attackers attacked their refugee convoy separating them from the women and children and executing them.
October 13 - 25 people including 13 soldiers when Jihadists attacked and burned down a military base in Mali then ambushed the reinforcements sent to the base.
October 16 - 20 people were killed in a jihadist attack on three villages.
